Led by Helm Rudi Barman, they braved breaking 2m waves and whipping force 7 winds to reach Andrew McGeown. They brought him to shore and did everything they could to revive him. Tragically, Andrew was beyond help. Rudi received the RNLI’s Bronze Medal for Gallantry for his leadership, boathandling skills and bravery. ‘I don’t think anything can ever prepare you for a rescue like that,’ he says. ‘It was the most difficult rescue I’ve been on. But it’s something we train for day in, day out. To be recognised with an award like this is a great honour, but it’s not just me. There are many different wheels that work in this station down to the people who have trained me and the crew over the years.’

column71: The annual report describes movingly how the fate of a child can be changed by the surgery to address a cleft palate, since the child may be withdrawn or ostracised as a result of their disfigurement. However it gives no indication of how widespread this is; while I am confident that there are some cultures who would ostracise children with a cleft palate, I would speculate that a material proportion (maybe the majority?) of the children helped were in fact quite happy with their lives before the intervention, and that while the intervention would have been (presumably) viewed positively by the beneficiary and his/her family at the time, would likely have done little to improve their lives (note that this is pure speculation; the charity provides no evidence to confirm or deny this). The rating of 3 assumes that the surgery can on occasions be life-changingly positive, and in other cases would render the beneficiary's life not materially better - more evidence would be needed to justify a higher rating. Update: found some research here, which seems to suggest that it's moderately cost-effective: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20063097. There's also this study too: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22986629

At six years old, Osawa Owiti already faced more than his fair share of hardships. Born in a remote village in Tanzania, he was the only child his fellow villagers had known to be born with a cleft. Even relatives treated Osawa differently. He became painfully shy and never laughed, so to not draw attention to his cleft lip.
His mother was also subject to tremendous criticism, unjustly blamed by her in-laws for Osawa’s cleft. The family of six, including his father and three siblings, persevered, remaining close despite the stigma surrounding Osawa.
Thanks to Smile Train donors and the skilled surgeons at Comprehensive Community Based Rehabilitation Hospital in Tanzania, Osawa received the life changing cleft surgery that he so desperately needed.
After the surgery Osawa’s mother stated, “My husband and I are forever grateful to Smile Train and its supporters for giving Osawa not just a new smile, but a fresh start at a life with opportunities.”

column71: Getting pets microchipped becomes valuable only when the pet is lost. According to "Frequency of Lost Dogs and Cats in the United States and the Methods Used to Locate Them" (www.mdpi.com/2076-2615/2/2/301/pdf) 15% of dogs are lost, and of those most are found by just searching the neighbourhood - only 14% of that 15% actually benefit from the microchip. In other words, only around 2% of those actually benefit from the chip, so that intervention gets a 1 out of 5 for its impactfulness. Neutering is also a valuable intervention because it stops the dog from breeding, which would be difficult to manage, however this is a qualified opinion, since according to http://www.yourpurebredpuppy.com/health/articles/neutering-male-dog.html , it can triple the risk of obesity, increase the risk of a cancer called hemangiosarcoma, triple the risk of hypothyroidism, increase the risk of geriatric cognitive impairment, and other risks. On balance it's still positive and gets a 4 out of 5. Caring for rehomed dogs is clearly 5 out of 5, since their condition without that care would be terrible.

column58: After a traumatic separation from her husband, Brenda was forced to rent with her two daughters. What first seemed like a cottage in a dream location soon turned into a living nightmare. Tiles fell from the walls. Wallpaper peeled off from damp. The ceiling in the lounge collapsed. But when Brenda’s solicitor wrote to the landlord on her behalf, the response was an eviction notice. Brenda and her family had two months to leave. That’s when our adviser Kellie took up her case. The strong defence that Shelter put forward meant the judge halted the action, and Brenda had time to find somewhere safe for her family to live.

column58: Annet Jane was only 14 when she became pregnant with her first and only child. Her water broke at night, and she planned to labour at home until the next morning, when she and her husband would borrow a bicycle for the 18-mile trip to the nearest hospital. Tragically, she lost the baby. The prolonged labour also left her with a fistula (a hole between the vagina and rectum or bladder). Twenty-three years later, through a fistula clinic at our partner clinic at Fistula Foundation's partner site CoRSU Rehabilitation Hospital in Uganda, Annet Jane was finally able to receive treatment. column71: A video at https://www.sendacow.org/how-we-work shows that before their work, 23% of respondents were confident of being able to provide for their families, with 97% saying that they were confident after doing the training. Not clear how to reconcile this with the fact that only around 20% of those doing the course then "graduate" - I'm inclined to disregard the study shown in the video, as it seems likely that the respondents are biased to respond positively. And what's more, confidence doesn't really mean anything - the important question is whether they actually got a higher income at the end of it. I think the most important question is how big an impact does it make for he 1620 households who "graduate" - do they see a big increase in income? I'm going to guess yes.However the dilution effect means that the overall impact can't be too high - c 20% of the 7,653 beneficiaries will have a (presumably) big improvement lives, others a bit of help, and others minimal impact. Averaging this out to an impact of 3 seems right. More info may arrive, which may change this assessment. Note that a comparison with Bees For Development seems to suggest that BfD is much better, with a lower cost per beneficiary, and without any of the complications that arrive from giving goods to beneficiaries.

column58: Over one billion people worldwide lack access to healthcare because they live too far from a health facility (World Health Organization, 2010). This problem is particularly acute in remote Liberia, where people living in communities furthest from the reach of the health system must walk for hours and across great distances to reach the nearest clinic. The impact of lack of access to care on health outcomes can be devastating: Liberia has among the highest maternal and child mortality rates in the world. Professionalized Community Health Workers (CHWs) are uniquely positioned to overcome this access gap. Comments and information about impact (even at outputs level) is poor. Could reasonably argue that the accounts say that the charity has zero impact, because the SOFA states (p11) that the expenditure is around two thirds fundraising costs and one third governance expenses, and zero on charitable activities. In reality, this is probably just poor accounting practice, since pages 20-21 seem to indicate that a material sum has been spent on guest speakers/preachers, radio/tv ministry and volunteer expenses. No mention was made of the sale of olive oil, however, nor of the 10 year battle against extradition from Kenya that Gilbert Deya faces, nor of the fact that his wife is guilty of child trafficking, although these facts have gathered more attention elsewhere (http://www.thirdsector.co.uk/charity-commission-investigates-charity-sells-healing-olive-oil/governance/article/1406256 http://www.itv.com/news/london/2016-01-25/archbishop-of-peckham-defiant-after-sting-reveals-fake-cancer-cure-claims/) Several of the cost items look surprisingly high - e.g. interest payable of £137k or legal fees of £85k. The interest of £137k and the depreciation of £54k may in fact be fine, given that the balance sheet seems to indicate that the charity does own property, however this would raise the question of why the charity needed to spend over £100k on rent. Overall, it looks suspicious.

column46: The cup trust has now been all but wound down, however I looked at the most recent set of accounts available, which is a few years old. The activities gave no indication of the number of beneficiaries. In fact, very unusually, it made no meaningful mention of any charitable activity at all - any talk about activity was focused on raising funds. The language was defensive. And the reserves were surprisingly small given the amount of income. When I tried to understand anything about the financial position, I was flummoxed by the fact that the charity received £78.9m, and then "spent" £78.9m on "buying gilts". Bizarrely, after buying the gilts, the money seems to have just vanished, thus breaking a fundamental of accounting (and a rule of how the world works) namely after you buy gilts, you have gilts. The Cup Trust bought gilts and this caused money to disappear. This set of accounts reeked so horrifically that I'm surprised nobody noticed it for so long
